topics.body:
Something I've been wondering about.

What were naval battles like in the Middle Ages?
I always see depictions of Roman antiquity era and Colonial Era styles of naval warfare. But very few Medieval ones.

topics.body:
"@SquiggyBomb":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/534b60ba6368722535840000#post_534b60ba6368722535840000

The style of warfare up until the advent of sail and its show of force at the "Battle of Lepanto":https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Lepanto has always involved ramming or boarding the other ship. The Italian Merchant Republics would often row their ships up next to each other, secure the two, then fight on giant floatsam of blood and violence until everyone died.

And there was no retreat, you'd fight or drown. There's no third-way. They followed the ancient traditions set down by the Greeks and Romans.

Hell, ramming and boarding again became a thing at the advent of armored battleships in the late 19th century. There's a few battles (in particular the "Battle of Lissa":https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Lissa_(1866) between Austria and Italy) where both navies were trying to ram each other. The invention of the ironclad sort of made guns irrelevant again when shells could rarely pierce armor, so ships just sort of became floating artillery pieces for lighter ships or landing support, they had to otherwise drive right into each other to be effective.

Once Armor Piercing and High Explosive ordinance came into the mainstream, ramming went out as a conventional tactic and was only used a few times since, I think mostly as the last or a desperate act.


And since I invoked the Battle of Lisa I just got to invoke this painting on Anton Romako:

!https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/68/Anton_Romako_001.jpg!

topics.body:
"@SquiggyBomb":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/534b63ed6368720959330000#post_534b63ed6368720959330000

There'd be some finesse into it since naval combat is about maneuvering for the most part. In the Battle of Lissa the Austrians beat the Italians despite being outnumbered two-to-one, but that's because they had managed to get the Italian force divided and they became very ineffective. And when the "main" part of the battle happened the Austrians managed to get the Italian force down enough that they out numbered them.

You also got the internal politics going on within the navies. The two guys in command of the Italian effort basically hated each other and one refused to join the battle because he hated the other so much.

Am I the only one that thinks the whole, "keep vampires and stuff hidden from humans" trope is stupid?  What I mean by that is if I was a mythological vampire I would walk straight up to a company that makes it's profits through medical research and go, "Yo dude, biologically immortal beings would be a insanely high profit and people would be throwing hundreds of billions of dollars at you to develop it.  Well I'm a mythological vampire, hire me to study my biology and you got it".  Considering how much money there would be in making medicine that makes it to where people are biologically immortal would have a insanely high profit in the end and I would probably be one of the richest people alive.
